title: Base item
data:
In *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*, the **base item** of an [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") is the type of [item](/wiki/Item "Item") that the artifact appears as. When an artifact is unidentified, it will be described as a named variation of its base item, e.g. "a blessed [amulet of ESP](/wiki/Amulet_of_ESP "Amulet of ESP") named [The Eye of the Aethiopica](/wiki/The_Eye_of_the_Aethiopica "The Eye of the Aethiopica")".

Artifacts will have all the properties of their base items in addition to any of the artifact's special abilities. If your [quest artifact](/wiki/Quest_artifact "Quest artifact") or any other artifact that already exists in your current game would be found in a [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones") level, the bones artifact will be reverted to its normal base item.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Rare base items](#Rare_base_items)
  - [1.1 Other base items](#Other_base_items)

- [2 Naming base items](#Naming_base_items)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Variants](#Variants)

  - [4.1 SporkHack](#SporkHack)
  - [4.2 EvilHack](#EvilHack)

## Rare base items

The following base items are not randomly generated on the floor or as death drops in a vanilla game of *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*:

- [athame](/wiki/Athame "Athame") ([Magicbane](/wiki/Magicbane "Magicbane"))
- [runesword](/wiki/Runesword "Runesword") ([Stormbringer](/wiki/Stormbringer "Stormbringer"))
- [tsurugi](/wiki/Tsurugi "Tsurugi") ([Tsurugi of Muramasa](/wiki/Tsurugi_of_Muramasa "Tsurugi of Muramasa"))

In addition to bones, athames very infrequently appear in the [starting inventory](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") of a [master lich](/wiki/Master_lich "Master lich"), [arch-lich](/wiki/Arch-lich "Arch-lich") or a [player monster](/wiki/Player_monster "Player monster") [wizard](/wiki/Wizard_\(player_monster\) "Wizard (player monster)"), making it possible for the player to obtain at least one eventually. The other two are not randomly generated at all, and are generally only found in a bones level during a game where you have already generated their artifacts; these base items can also be obtained by [wishing](/wiki/Wishing "Wishing").

### Other base items

The items used for the [Invocation](/wiki/Invocation "Invocation"), referred to as [unique items](/wiki/Unique_items "Unique items") by the game, have unique base appearances when unidentified:

- silver [bell](/wiki/Bell "Bell") ([Bell of Opening](/wiki/Bell_of_Opening "Bell of Opening"))
- candelabrum ([Candelabrum of Invocation](/wiki/Candelabrum_of_Invocation "Candelabrum of Invocation"))
- papyrus [spellbook](/wiki/Spellbook "Spellbook") ([Book of the Dead](/wiki/Book_of_the_Dead "Book of the Dead"))

While not considered artifacts by the game, these "invocation artifacts" function similarly - they are also "one-per-game" objects, but cannot ever be wished for in any form, since they will appear in every game. Attempting a wish for one will instead give the player a more mundane counterpart (i.e. a regular bell, a [candle](/wiki/Candle "Candle"), and a [blank spellbook](/wiki/Blank_spellbook "Blank spellbook") respectively); the items will also revert to these mundane forms when found in a bones file.

## Naming base items

[Sting](/wiki/Sting "Sting") and [Orcrist](/wiki/Orcrist "Orcrist") are special among artifacts in that they can be created by using the #[name](/wiki/Name "Name") or #[call](/wiki/Call "Call") command to name their base items. Any [elven dagger](/wiki/Elven_dagger "Elven dagger") can be named Sting to create it, while any [elven broadsword](/wiki/Elven_broadsword "Elven broadsword") can be named Orcrist to create it.

Creating Sting and Orcrist early via naming is commonly used to "force" [Stormbringer](/wiki/Stormbringer "Stormbringer") as the first [sacrifice gift](/wiki/Sacrifice_gift "Sacrifice gift") for a [chaotic](/wiki/Chaotic "Chaotic") character, since naming both artifacts only leaves Stormbringer and [Grimtooth](/wiki/Grimtooth "Grimtooth") as the remaining chaotic-aligned artifacts in the sacrifice gift pool; elves are a common choice for players attempting this, as they will never receive Grimtooth as a sacrifice gift. However, the chances of receiving an artifact as a sacrifice gift after the first are decreased, as are your chances of receiving an artifact via wishing. Each weapon also has its own pros and cons with regards to early creation; see the articles on Sting and Orcrist for more information on each.

## History

In [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") and earlier versions, including some variants based on these versions, the [naming artifacts](/wiki/Naming_artifacts "Naming artifacts") trick could be used to distinguish the identities of certain base items such as [luckstones](/wiki/Luckstone "Luckstone"); this is a result of the code to prevent non-artifacts being made into artifacts via naming. Specifically, attempting to give an object an artifact's name, outside of the aforementioned Sting and Orcrist, forces your hand to slip and mis-engrave it—but *only* if that object is of the same exact item type as the artifact's base item, e.g. naming a [gray stone](/wiki/Gray_stone "Gray stone") [The Heart of Ahriman](/wiki/The_Heart_of_Ahriman "The Heart of Ahriman") would only mis-engrave if it was a luckstone.

This is fixed in [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0") by having any attempt to name an item in the same category as an artifact after that artifact fail and force your hand to slip - e.g., any gray stone will now mis-engrave if named The Heart of Ahriman.

## Variants

### SporkHack

[SporkHack](/wiki/SporkHack "SporkHack") adds a few new base items to go with changes to some of the artifacts:

- [silver mace](/wiki/Silver_mace "Silver mace") (new base item for [Demonbane](/wiki/Demonbane "Demonbane"))

### EvilHack

[EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack") adds several more artifacts and changes the base items of many existing artifacts:

- [atlatl](/index.php?title=Atlatl\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Atlatl (page does not exist)") (base item for [Xiuhcoatl](/index.php?title=Xiuhcoatl\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Xiuhcoatl (page does not exist)"))
- [eight ball](/wiki/Eight_ball "Eight ball") (base item for the [Magic 8-Ball](/wiki/Magic_8-Ball "Magic 8-Ball"))
- [heavy mace](/wiki/Heavy_mace "Heavy mace") (new base item for [Demonbane](/wiki/Demonbane "Demonbane"))
- [heavy war hammer](/wiki/Heavy_war_hammer "Heavy war hammer") (new base item for [Mjollnir](/wiki/Mjollnir "Mjollnir") and [Ogresmasher](/wiki/Ogresmasher "Ogresmasher"))
- [rod](/wiki/Rod "Rod") (base item for the [Wand of Orcus](/wiki/Wand_of_Orcus_\(EvilHack\) "Wand of Orcus (EvilHack)"), new base item for the [Sceptre of Might](/wiki/Sceptre_of_Might "Sceptre of Might"))
- [triple-headed flail](/wiki/Triple-headed_flail "Triple-headed flail") (base item for [Butcher](/wiki/Butcher "Butcher"))

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")
html:
Base item

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

In NetHack, the base item of an artifact is the type of item that the artifact appears as. When an artifact is unidentified, it will be described as a named variation of its base item, e.g. "a blessed amulet of ESP named The Eye of the Aethiopica".

Artifacts will have all the properties of their base items in addition to any of the artifact's special abilities. If your quest artifact or any other artifact that already exists in your current game would be found in a bones level, the bones artifact will be reverted to its normal base item.

Contents

  • 1 Rare base items
    • 1.1 Other base items
  • 2 Naming base items
  • 3 History
  • 4 Variants
    • 4.1 SporkHack
    • 4.2 EvilHack

Rare base items

The following base items are not randomly generated on the floor or as death drops in a vanilla game of NetHack:

  • athame (Magicbane)
  • runesword (Stormbringer)
  • tsurugi (Tsurugi of Muramasa)

In addition to bones, athames very infrequently appear in the starting inventory of a master lich, arch-lich or a player monster wizard, making it possible for the player to obtain at least one eventually. The other two are not randomly generated at all, and are generally only found in a bones level during a game where you have already generated their artifacts; these base items can also be obtained by wishing.

Other base items

The items used for the Invocation, referred to as unique items by the game, have unique base appearances when unidentified:

  • silver bell (Bell of Opening)
  • candelabrum (Candelabrum of Invocation)
  • papyrus spellbook (Book of the Dead)

While not considered artifacts by the game, these "invocation artifacts" function similarly - they are also "one-per-game" objects, but cannot ever be wished for in any form, since they will appear in every game. Attempting a wish for one will instead give the player a more mundane counterpart (i.e. a regular bell, a candle, and a blank spellbook respectively); the items will also revert to these mundane forms when found in a bones file.

Naming base items

Sting and Orcrist are special among artifacts in that they can be created by using the #name or #call command to name their base items. Any elven dagger can be named Sting to create it, while any elven broadsword can be named Orcrist to create it.

Creating Sting and Orcrist early via naming is commonly used to "force" Stormbringer as the first sacrifice gift for a chaotic character, since naming both artifacts only leaves Stormbringer and Grimtooth as the remaining chaotic-aligned artifacts in the sacrifice gift pool; elves are a common choice for players attempting this, as they will never receive Grimtooth as a sacrifice gift. However, the chances of receiving an artifact as a sacrifice gift after the first are decreased, as are your chances of receiving an artifact via wishing. Each weapon also has its own pros and cons with regards to early creation; see the articles on Sting and Orcrist for more information on each.

History

In NetHack 3.4.3 and earlier versions, including some variants based on these versions, the naming artifacts trick could be used to distinguish the identities of certain base items such as luckstones; this is a result of the code to prevent non-artifacts being made into artifacts via naming. Specifically, attempting to give an object an artifact's name, outside of the aforementioned Sting and Orcrist, forces your hand to slip and mis-engrave it—but only if that object is of the same exact item type as the artifact's base item, e.g. naming a gray stone The Heart of Ahriman would only mis-engrave if it was a luckstone.

This is fixed in NetHack 3.6.0 by having any attempt to name an item in the same category as an artifact after that artifact fail and force your hand to slip - e.g., any gray stone will now mis-engrave if named The Heart of Ahriman.

Variants

SporkHack

SporkHack adds a few new base items to go with changes to some of the artifacts:

  • silver mace (new base item for Demonbane)

EvilHack

EvilHack adds several more artifacts and changes the base items of many existing artifacts:

  • atlatl (base item for Xiuhcoatl)
  • eight ball (base item for the Magic 8-Ball)
  • heavy mace (new base item for Demonbane)
  • heavy war hammer (new base item for Mjollnir and Ogresmasher)
  • rod (base item for the Wand of Orcus, new base item for the Sceptre of Might)
  • triple-headed flail (base item for Butcher)
Retrieved from "https://nethackwiki.com/index.php?title=Base_item&oldid=163538"

rawPage:
In ''[[NetHack]]'', the '''base item''' of an [[artifact]] is the type of [[item]] that the artifact appears as. When an artifact is unidentified, it will be described as a named variation of its base item, e.g. "a blessed [[amulet of ESP]] named [[The Eye of the Aethiopica]]".

Artifacts will have all the properties of their base items in addition to any of the artifact's special abilities. If your [[quest artifact]] or any other artifact that already exists in your current game would be found in a [[bones]] level, the bones artifact will be reverted to its normal base item.

==Rare base items==
The following base items are not randomly generated on the floor or as death drops in a vanilla game of ''[[NetHack]]'':

* [[athame]] ([[Magicbane]])
* [[runesword]] ([[Stormbringer]])
* [[tsurugi]] ([[Tsurugi of Muramasa]])

In addition to bones, athames very infrequently appear in the [[Monster starting inventory|starting inventory]] of a [[master lich]], [[arch-lich]] or a [[player monster]] [[wizard (player monster)|wizard]], making it possible for the player to obtain at least one eventually. The other two are not randomly generated at all, and are generally only found in a bones level during a game where you have already generated their artifacts; these base items can also be obtained by [[wishing]].

===Other base items===
The items used for the [[Invocation]], referred to as [[unique items]] by the game, have unique base appearances when unidentified:

* silver [[bell]] ([[Bell of Opening]])
* candelabrum ([[Candelabrum of Invocation]])
* papyrus [[spellbook]] ([[Book of the Dead]])

While not considered artifacts by the game, these "invocation artifacts" function similarly - they are also "one-per-game" objects, but cannot ever be wished for in any form, since they will appear in every game. Attempting a wish for one will instead give the player a more mundane counterpart (i.e. a regular bell, a [[candle]], and a [[blank spellbook]] respectively); the items will also revert to these mundane forms when found in a bones file.

==Naming base items==
[[Sting]] and [[Orcrist]] are special among artifacts in that they can be created by using the #[[name]] or #[[call]] command to name their base items. Any [[elven dagger]] can be named Sting to create it, while any [[elven broadsword]] can be named Orcrist to create it.

Creating Sting and Orcrist early via naming is commonly used to "force" [[Stormbringer]] as the first [[sacrifice gift]] for a [[chaotic]] character, since naming both artifacts only leaves Stormbringer and [[Grimtooth]] as the remaining chaotic-aligned artifacts in the sacrifice gift pool; elves are a common choice for players attempting this, as they will never receive Grimtooth as a sacrifice gift. However, the chances of receiving an artifact as a sacrifice gift after the first are decreased, as are your chances of receiving an artifact via wishing. Each weapon also has its own pros and cons with regards to early creation; see the articles on Sting and Orcrist for more information on each.

==History==
In [[NetHack 3.4.3]] and earlier versions, including some variants based on these versions, the [[naming artifacts]] trick could be used to distinguish the identities of certain base items such as [[luckstone]]s; this is a result of the code to prevent non-artifacts being made into artifacts via naming. Specifically, attempting to give an object an artifact's name, outside of the aforementioned Sting and Orcrist, forces your hand to slip and mis-engrave it—but ''only'' if that object is of the same exact item type as the artifact's base item, e.g. naming a [[gray stone]] [[The Heart of Ahriman]] would only mis-engrave if it was a luckstone.

This is fixed in [[NetHack 3.6.0]] by having any attempt to name an item in the same category as an artifact after that artifact fail and force your hand to slip - e.g., any gray stone will now mis-engrave if named The Heart of Ahriman.

==Variants==
===SporkHack===
[[SporkHack]] adds a few new base items to go with changes to some of the artifacts:

* [[silver mace]] (new base item for [[Demonbane]])

===EvilHack===
[[EvilHack]] adds several more artifacts and changes the base items of many existing artifacts:

* [[atlatl]] (base item for [[Xiuhcoatl]])
* [[eight ball]] (base item for the [[Magic 8-Ball]])
* [[heavy mace]] (new base item for [[Demonbane]])
* [[heavy war hammer]] (new base item for [[Mjollnir]] and [[Ogresmasher]])
* [[rod]] (base item for the [[Wand of Orcus (EvilHack)|Wand of Orcus]], new base item for the [[Sceptre of Might]])
* [[triple-headed flail]] (base item for [[Butcher]])
